Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

Joshua,

It seems that the header files needed to build C++ applications got 
left out of cantera-1.5.3-src.zip.  I would recommend getting Cantera 
from sourceforge via CVS if at all possible.  That insures that you 
have the latest version.

Assuming you have a CVS client (you probably do if you are running 
Dev-C++), then the following commands will check out the latest copy of 
Cantera:

cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@...:/cvsroot/cantera login
cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@...:/cvsroot/cantera co 
cantera

When asked for a password for user anonymous, simply hit 'return'.

One thing you may need to do is edit the 'configure' script and set 
USE_VISUAL_STUDIO to 'n'.  Then run 'configure' and you should be all 
set.

Dave Goodwin


On May 27, 2004, at 8:34 AM, Joshua Pence wrote:

> I am having a bit of a problem with compiling Cantera in Dev-C++.
>
> Apparently, I do not have the 'Cantera' header file ('Cantera.h') on
> my system, although I have downloaded it (Cantera153) off sourceforge
> several times.  It simply isn't in here.  Do I need other software
> than the package that is available on sourceforge?
>
> Joshua
>
>

Joshua,


It seems that the header files needed to build C++ applications got
left out of cantera-1.5.3-src.zip.  I would recommend getting Cantera
from sourceforge via CVS if at all possible.  That insures that you
have the latest version.


Assuming you have a CVS client (you probably do if you are running
Dev-C++), then the following commands will check out the latest copy
of Cantera:

-d:pserver:anonymous@...:/cvsroot/cantera login 

cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@...:/cvsroot/cantera co
cantera


</x-tad-bigger></fontfamily>When asked for a password for user
anonymous, simply hit 'return'.


One thing you may need to do is edit the 'configure' script and set
USE_VISUAL_STUDIO to 'n'.  Then run 'configure' and you should be all
set. 


Dave Goodwin



On May 27, 2004, at 8:34 AM, Joshua Pence wrote:


<excerpt>I am having a bit of a problem with compiling Cantera in
Dev-C++.


Apparently, I do not have the 'Cantera' header file ('Cantera.h') on

my system, although I have downloaded it (Cantera153) off sourceforge

several times.  It simply isn't in here.  Do I need other software

than the package that is available on sourceforge?  


Joshua
